verses.text: In the seventh year of Jehu, Jehoash became king, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zibiah of Beersheba.
verses.comment: Maintains original names; Jehoash and Joash are interchangeable in manuscripts.

verses.text: Jehoash did what was right in the sight of the LORD all his days, because Jehoiada the priest instructed him.
verses.comment: Clarifies Jehoiada’s role in guiding Joash, as in the original.

verses.text: However, the high places were not removed; the people still sacrificed and burned incense on the high places.
verses.comment: Retains the high places issue, as often in Kings.

verses.text: And Jehoash said to the priests, "All the money brought as sacred gifts into the house of the LORD—the money from each man's census, the assessment money, and all the money that a man purposes in his heart to bring into the house of the LORD—"
verses.comment: Enumerates the types of offerings and assessments per Levitical law.

verses.text: "Let the priests take it, each from his acquaintance, and they shall repair any damage found in the house wherever damage is discovered."
verses.comment: Retains the instruction to priests to oversee repairs.

verses.text: But by the twenty-third year of King Jehoash, the priests had not repaired the damage to the house.
verses.comment: Direct statement of delay.

verses.text: Then King Jehoash called Jehoiada the priest and the other priests and said to them, "Why are you not repairing the damage to the house? Now, do not take any more money from your acquaintances, but give it toward repairing the house."
verses.comment: Joash’s rebuke is preserved; instruction transferred.

verses.text: So the priests agreed that they would not take any more money from the people, nor repair the damage of the house themselves.
verses.comment: Division of responsibility made clear.

verses.text: Then Jehoiada the priest took a chest, bored a hole in its lid, and placed it beside the altar, on the right side as one comes into the house of the LORD. The priests guarding the threshold put in all the money that was brought into the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Describes the creation of the collection chest per tradition.

verses.text: Whenever they saw that there was a large amount of money in the chest, the king’s secretary and the high priest would come up, count the money brought into the house of the LORD, and bag it.
verses.comment: Makes the process of collection and recording explicit.

verses.text: Then they would give the money weighed out into the hands of those who did the work, who oversaw the house of the LORD. They paid it out to the carpenters and builders who worked on the house of the LORD,
verses.comment: Refers to supervisors and tradesmen as in original.

verses.text: and to the masons and stonecutters, and to buy timber and cut stone to repair the damage to the house of the LORD, and for all expenses for repairing the house.
verses.comment: Materials and trades clarified per Hebrew terms.

verses.text: However, there were no silver cups, snuffers, basins, trumpets, or any articles of gold or silver made for the house of the LORD from the money brought into the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: No utensils made; only repairs funded.

verses.text: They gave it to those who did the work, and with it they repaired the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Summarizes use of funds.

verses.text: Moreover, they did not require an accounting from the men to whom they gave the money to pay to the workers, for they dealt faithfully.
verses.comment: Affirms trustworthiness of the workers.

verses.text: The money from guilt offerings and sin offerings was not brought into the house of the LORD; it belonged to the priests.
verses.comment: Distinction made between offerings and temple repair funds.

verses.text: At that time, Hazael king of Aram went up and fought against Gath and captured it. Then Hazael set his face to go up against Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Preserves geographic and military context.

verses.text: Jehoash king of Judah took all the sacred objects that his fathers Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, kings of Judah, had dedicated, and his own sacred objects, and all the gold found in the treasuries of the house of the LORD and in the king’s house, and sent them to Hazael king of Aram. Then Hazael withdrew from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Details spoil and tribute given to Hazael.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Jehoash, and all that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Traditional phrase for historical closure.

verses.text: Jehoash’s servants arose and conspired against him, and killed Jehoash in the house of Millo, which goes down to Silla.
verses.comment: Maintains the location per textual tradition; 'house of Millo' is obscure but retained.

verses.text: For Jozacar, the son of Shimeath, and Jehozabad, the son of Shomer, his servants, struck him, and he died. So they buried him with his fathers in the city of David. Amaziah his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Clarifies the assassin’s names and succession.
